title: ASC submarine workers strike over Federal Government's enterprise bargaining agreement - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
ASC submarine workers strike over Federal Government's enterprise bargaining agreement Posted February 23, 2017 09:02:26 Map: Osborne 5017 
Hundreds of workers have walked off the job at Adelaide shipbuilder ASC over an ongoing enterprise bargaining dispute that has spanned two years. 
About 25 night shift workers have been on strike since Sunday and another 200 submarine workers have stopped work for the next 72 hours as a disagreement over their enterprise bargaining agreement negotiations intensifies. 
Another 400 workers from the company's ship building arm will strike for an hour this morning in a symbol of support for their submarine colleagues, before a union lead meeting takes place. 
Colin Fenney from the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union claimed the Federal Government was trying to impose public sector conditions on ASC workers through a new enterprise agreement. 
He told ABC Adelaide it was also demanding unrealistic productivity gains. 
"The last fixed cycle document of a submarine was done here in two years, now before that, the last one was done in three and a half years so the productivity gain there is incredible and it's not being recognised by the Federal Government," Mr Fenney said. 
"Now when you look at our colleagues next door on the AWD [Air Warfare Destroyer] project that has increased by 40 per cent in productivity with these current agreements we have in place." 
Mr Fenney said workers were also frustrated by how long it was taking to negotiate the new enterprise agreement. 
"It's just frustration ... and we've asked for the people that are making the decisions in Government to come and sit around the table with us, sit here in front of us so we can get this thing fixed and get it on with," he said. 
"The Government just needs to just step aside and let the workers and the company get on with it." 
Mr Fenney said all stop work action was legal. 
A meeting today will decide the workers' next step of action.
